conclusion: Understanding the setup of the problem with a point light source, a ball, and a wall.
The ball is thrown vertically upward with initial velocity \( v_0 \) and experiences gravitational acceleration \( g \).
The vertical position of the ball as a function of time is \( y(t) = v_0 t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \).
The shadow's position is determined by the geometry of the light source, ball, and wall.
Using similar triangles, the position of the shadow \( y_s \) is related to the position of the ball \( y(t) \) by \( \frac{y_s}{L} = \frac{y(t)}{x} \).
The velocity of the shadow \( v_s \) is proportional to the velocity of the ball.
The velocity of the ball is \( v(t) = v_0 - g t \).
The velocity of the shadow \( v_s \) is \( v_s = \left( \frac{L}{x} \right) v(t) \).
At \( t = 0 \), the initial velocity of the shadow is \( v_s(0) = \left( \frac{L}{x} \right) v_0 \).
If the midpoint is equidistant from the light source and the wall, \( x = \frac{L}{2} \), then \( v_s(0) = 2 v_0 \).
The initial velocity of the shadow is \( 2v_0 \).
